2.title: La Historia a Través de la Historieta : una reinterpretación de la independencia de Cuba en 'La historia de Elpidio Valdés'
2.author: Ana Merino.

3.heading: La Historia Argentina en Pedazos de Historietas.
3.title: "Unhil, Unión de Historietistas e Ilustradores de Tucumán : La Historia Argentina en Pedazos de Historietas"
3.author: César Carrizo
3.appears_in: p. 114-124 in Revista Latinoamericana de Estudios sobre la Historieta, v. 2, no. 6 (Junio 2002).
notes: Resumen: "Conocer el marco histórico y las proyecciones con que nace la Unhil de Tucumán y su faceta de diferenciación de las múltiples y repetidas características de la historieta en tierra tucumana, así como el entorn social y político que la antecedió y hoy la sustenta, es el objeto de este breve trabajo."

Abstract: To bring to light how the Unhil of Tucumán was founded and differentiated from other characteristic area comics, as well as how the social and political environment that preceded it still supports it today, is the main purpose of this brief work.
Abstracts as printed with the article, with some editing of the English.

20.heading: Historia de la Historieta Argentina.
20.title: Oesterheld : Una Aventura Interior
20.author: Guillermo Saccomanno, Carlos Trillo
20.appears_in: p. 237-256 in La Revista Latinoamericana de Estudios sobre la Historieta, v. 1, no. 4 (Dic. 2001).
notes: Resumen: "No hace falta resumir el contenido de ese articulo que, después de más de veinte años, repropone, con una nueva introducción actualizada, la famosa cuanto deste hace tiempo imposible de hallar entrevista que los autores hicieron a Héctor Germán Oesterheld y publicaron en su agotadisima 'Historia de la Historieta Argentina' (Ediciones Récord, Buenos Aires, 1980). Como es noto se trata del documento más amplio y profundizado que nos queda a propósito de la figura fundamental de los años de oro de la historieta argentina. En este número se publica la sola entrevista, mientras se posterga al próximo la útil cronologia que en libro citado la acompaña."

Abstract: It is not necessary to summarize the content of this article that, after more than twenty years, represents, with a new updated introduction, the famous but long impossible to find interview that the authors did with Héctor Germán Oesterheld and published in their sold out 'Historia de la Historieta Argentina' (Ediciones Récord, Buenos Aires, 1980). As is well-known, it is the the most complete and penetrating document we have with regard to the fundamental figure of the golden years of Argentine comics. In this issue only the interview is published, while the useful chronology that accompanies it in the book mentioned is delayed until next issue.
Abstracts as published with the article, with some editing of the English.

notes: Summary (by M. Harbeck): An educational story about the first colonization of Brazil mentioning the first settlements, the organization of the administration, and the first acculturations on Portuguese and Indian side (bananas, hammocks, clothes).

76.title: "Historia do Brasil em Figuras: O descobrimento do Brasil"
76.author: Leonidas
76.appears_in: p. 12-13 in O Tico-Tico : Jornal das Crianças, no. 3 (Oct. 25, 1905).
notes: Summary (by M. Harbeck): Educational picture story about the discovery of Brazil by a Portuguese fleet commanded by Pedro Alvarez Cabral in 1500 and about their first encounter with the native Americans. Mentions a letter Pero Vaz de Caminha wrote and which was delivered to the Portuguese king.

77.title: História do Brasil para Principiantes : de Cabral a Cardoso, 500 anos de Novela
77.author: Carlos Eduardo Novaes & César Lobo.

78.title: "Historia do Pai João
78.author: por Angelo Agostini
78.appears_in: p. 8-9 in O Tico-tico : Jornal das Crianças, no. 5 (Nov. 8, 1905).
notes: Summary (by M. Harbeck): Educational story about Brazilian slavery on a coffee plantation. The mistrusted African-Brazilian slave Pai João plots to convince the white plantation owner to dismiss the white overseer Deco and install João as the new overseer. Because of his cruelty the other slaves complain about him to the owner who reinstalls Deco and lets João gets punished and sold. Uses stereotypical African Portuguese language and clichés of racial relations.

88.title: The Historian, v. 54, no. 2
88.author: Jennifer K
88.series: Winter 1992) The Caricature of the Irish in British and U.S. Comic Art
notes: Detached from the Historian, v. 54, no. 2, (Winter 1992), p. 283-288.

SUMMARY: The Michigan State University Museum traveling exhibit, Pat-Riots to Patriots: American Irish in caricature and comic art, a collection of images assembled by John and Selma Appel, depicts the stereotyping of the Irish in Britain and the United States during the nineteenth and early twentieth centuries.
Exhibitions. I. Hardy, Jennifer K. II. Appel, John J., 1921- III. Appel, Selma. IV. Michigan State University. Museum. V. The Historian, v. 54, no. 2, (Winter 1992). Call no.: NC1310.E3 H3 1992

147.title: "The Historic City of Delhi : a Tale of Power and Passion"
147.author: script, Luis M
147.appears_in: Fernandes ; illustrations, Arvind Mandrekar ; editor, Anant Pai. p. 1-31 in Amar Chitra Katha, no. 696 (1983, 2010 printing).
notes: Summary from back cover: "Down its 1000-year-old recorded history, Delhi was razed and built several times. The city played host to many rulers like the Chauhans, the Slave kings, the Khiljis, the Tughlugs, the Mughals and the British. It suffered the brutalities of numerous invaders. Each ruler and each invader left his own special mark on the psyche of this great city. The historic city of Delhi presents a palette of colourful influences that truly reflects the composite culture of India."

156.title: Historic Virtuoso Cartoonists
156.author: exhibition curator: Lucy Shelton Caswell ; catalogue designer: Frank Pauer.

publication info.publisher: Ohio State University Cartoon Research Library

notes: "This catalogue is published as part of the 2001 Festival of Carton Art to accompany the exhibition Historic Virtuoso Cartoonists from August 26 through September 30, 2001 at the Columbus Recreation and Parks Department Cultural Arts Center."

Biographical sketches of Thomas Nast, Joseph Keppler, Frederick Burr Opper, Richard Felton Outcault, Winsor McCay, Nell Brinkley, George Herriman, Edwina Dumm, Rube Goldberg, Milton Caniff, Walt Kelly, Charles M. Schulz, Willard Mullin, James Thurber, Oliver Harrington, Art Young, Jay 'Ding' Darling, Rollin Kirby, and Jeff MacNelly.

Brief essays on cartoon virtuosity, with contributor notes for each, by Shelly Armitage, Kenneth Stacey Baker, Daniel Bolsinger, John Canemaker, N.C. Christopher Couch, Bill Crouch, Will Eisner, Roger A. Fischer, Thierry Groensteen, R.C. Harvey, M. Thomas Inge, Jim Ivey, Michael Kahn, Gene Kannenberg Jr., Amy Lago, John A. Lent, Jack Loftis, Patrick McDonnell, Toni Mendez, Roy Paul Nelson, Richard D. Olson, Charles Press, Trina Robbins, Lee Salem, Rob Stolzer, Steve Thompson, Brian Walker, Mort Walker, Judith Wechsler, Richard Samuel West, Bruce Wheltle, Malcolm Whyte, Glenda Winders, and Art Wood.
